TEXT: Dear, ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the alstria office REIT-AG Q3 Results 2017 Conference Call.
At our customer's request, this conference will be recorded.
(Operator Instructions)
May I now hand you over to Olivier Elamine, who will lead you through this conference.
Please go ahead, sir.
Thank you very much, and welcome, everybody, from cloudy Hamburg this morning for the 9 months result presentation of alstria.

I'm sitting here with Alexander Dexne, which is alstria's CFO; and Ralf Dibbern, which is our Head of Investor Relation, in order to walk you through the result of the company for the first 9 months of the year.

The business of alstria over the first 9 months of the year have developed according to our plans, with revenue at EUR 143.8 million; our FFO after minorities at slightly short of EUR 86 million, in line with our planning and on target to hit the guidance for the year.
The current FFO per share for the 3 quarters (inaudible) $0.56 per share.

We did have -- and I will come back to that in a minute, we did have and we did benefit from a relatively strong leasing backdrop in the market, and we're trying to take, as much as possible, advantage of that with newly signed, across -- since the beginning of the year of 68,600 square meters, and we have extended leases for 126,600 square meters with our EPRA vacancy rate, which remain roundabout stable at 9.3%.
But bear in mind, we have been acquiring assets, which have substantially more vacancy than we have in the portfolio, which, obviously, have an impact on the EPRA vacancy rate.
On the acquisition, we did acquire, as you know, and closed the portfolio, which we acquired from OFFICEFIRST.
And in total, over the -- since the beginning of the year, we acquired 13 assets for a total cost of EUR 188.4 million, which reflect a yield of around 6.1%.
And we did dispose of 4 noncore assets for a total consideration of EUR 60 million.
Since last time we reported, as a reminder, we also disposed the Kaisergalerie, the joint venture that we had here in Hamburg, for EUR 470 million, the total value.
Our share is 50% of that, at a buyer yield of around 3.9%.
Moving on into the financials, and I'd like to spend a little bit of time on this slide because there are a lot of things moving in parallel here.

Our gross rental income is down 7.5%, which basically essentially reflects the asset sales that we've been doing since the acquisition of Deutsche Office and the due that we have on the market where we're trying to, basically, capitalize on the very strong interest and the very high price that you can achieve today in the market.
I think if you were just to look at the asset sales that happened in the prior -- the period prior to reporting, we would have lost around EUR 19.7 million of revenues.

Part of that loss was recovered through the acquisition that we just discussed a few minutes ago, which represent EUR 3.5 million of additional income for the first 9 months of the year, and another EUR 5 million was recovered through a reduction of vacancy and lease up in the portfolio.
So out of the EUR 19.7 million of income that we have sold, we basically have an EUR 11.5 million impact year-on-year, which is reflected currently in our revenue.
Our fund from operation, on the other hand, has remained roundabout stable.
So despite the drop of 7.5% of the gross rental income, our fund from operation is pretty much comparable to last year, with a drop of 1.3% at EUR 85.9 million.

And that's -- we were able to achieve that mainly through a lower real estate operating cost; the synergy effect that you can also see on the SG&A, going down by almost EUR 1.3 million, around 8%; as well as lower financing costs, which represent around half of the savings on the fund from operations.
So we have here 2 or 3 effects.
First of all, the fact that we've been selling assets, which is partially compensated by the fact that we've been actively managing the portfolio and leasing in the portfolio.

And then, we're still benefiting from a reduction of financial costs and the synergy effects, which took place during the year, which helped us to, basically, keep the FFO in line with what it was last year.
If we move on to the balance sheet.

You can here again see on the investment property the impact of the recent acquisitions that we've made, with the total investment property on the balance sheet going up by EUR 170 million, which is above the amount that we have acquired.

And in parallel, while the investment properties go up by 5.7%, our long-term debt has grown by 1.1%, which reflects, basically, the view that we have on the market and our willingness to reduce those quantum of debt and LTV over time, until we have [under-leveraged] the acquisitions that we've made over the last few months, which explains why our investment property is growing much faster than the amount of debt on the balance sheet, and I'll come back to that in a minute.

On the equity side, you can see that our equity has grown by almost 2%, which is basically the combined effect of the EUR 80 million of dividend payment, which had a negative impact on the equity, and the EUR 111 million of future earning, which, obviously, have a positive effect on the equity.
Our G-REIT equity ratio is comfortably at 53.5%.
Our net LTV flattish, sort of, 44.5%, and our EPRA NAV per share at EUR 11.52.
We've been quite active over the last 12 months on working out our debt.

We believe that one of the major risks that are facing our industry going up in the future would be the increase of interest rate, and the most efficient way of managing that risk is to reduce the quantum of debt, which is on the balance sheet of the company.

And this is what we've been doing, we've been reducing the quantum of debt on our balance sheet by almost 17%, and paying back to EUR 242 million -- around EUR 300 million of debt, sorry, in the -- since last year, and that's really something where we're keen on continuing going forward.
We are working on both reducing the quantum of debt, but also on improving and managing proactively the debt maturity that we have and potentially extending the maturity.
I think there is a very strong market currently in the debt market from an interest rate perspective.
And this is something, I guess, we are looking at as much as everybody else out there.

But the main message here is, really, we are addressing proactively, mainly, the quantum of debt on the balance sheet, which we believe is the only way to sustainably manage the interest rate risk going forward and into the future.
On the portfolio, our EUR 3.2 billion portfolio.
Our EPRA vacancy rate, as you know, is at 9.3%.
Weighted average lease terms are quite stable at 4.8 years.
We have contractual rent of EUR 204.8 million, a valuation yield at 6.4%.
We have not revalued our assets during this year.
We still do it once a year, and that should come at the end of the year.
And the value per square meter, which is again relatively stable, slightly short of EUR 2,000 per square meter.
We are focusing our portfolio on the 5 geographical areas that you have on the map, which is Berlin, Hamburg, Düsseldorf, Frankfurt and Stuttgart.
And we've been working quite actively on managing the assets and refocusing the portfolio on those locations.
Which brings me to the next slide.
We've been pretty active in terms of working out the portfolio in terms of disposals and acquisitions.
And all of those, I think, we wanted just to highlight that it all folds together as part of our view of the market.
We are trying to achieve 2 things here in parallel.
The first one is to refocus the portfolio on offices and on the 5 markets that we are currently looking at, which is Hamburg, again, Düsseldorf, Frankfurt, Stuttgart and Berlin.
And at the same moment in time, we're also trying to reduce the average size of every -- each and every one of our assets.

We do believe that the bigger the assets are, the higher the risks you're taking and that there is a benefit into owning, potentially, more property, but smaller properties, looking at how the market is developing.
And we'll be happy to expand on that, either in the Q&A or when we meet you on the road.

But those are the 2 objectives we've been trying to do, and that's what's demonstrated on that slide, where you can see that we've been increasing the number of assets that we have in Hamburg, Düsseldorf, Frankfurt and Berlin, while we've been selling mainly outside of those cities.
And we've also been reducing the average size of the assets that we have in those cities.
And that, I think, is pretty evident in Berlin, where also we're increasing the number of assets that we have in the cities.
The number of square meters that we actually manage in Berlin has dropped quite dramatically, and that's basically the impact of the sales of the Treptowers.

The reason why we believe that it makes sense to reduce the sheer size of the asset is this is based on our experience on the lease up market, where the actual size, which is acquired by the tenant barely goes beyond the 20,000 square meter level.
We have been very active in the leasing markets.
We've leased roundabout almost one lease per day since the beginning of the year -- for every business day since the beginning of the year.
We are showing you here the largest leases that we have signed or renewed over the quarter.
So in total, we have signed 105 new leases, with an average lettable area of 653 square meters, and we have renewed around 53 leases with an average lettable area of 2,400 square meters.

What I find is interesting in this slide is, as you can see, is we're achieving, on average, a substantially higher rent on the new leases and the renewal, and that's basically simply the effect of the CapEx we're spending on the assets, which allow us to offer a higher-quality space, which then commands a slightly higher rent.

We still believe that, in order to increase rent in a property -- an asset property in Germany and probably elsewhere in continental Europe, there is a need for investment in CapEx, and that really is kind of the elephant in the room or the missing part of the overall equation, but this is basically how we achieved this higher rental income.

This being the third quarter this year, I think we've been now, for the last few years, publishing our sustainability report, and it gives us an opportunity, basically, to start looking at something else in the financials.
I would strongly encourage you to read our sustainability report, there is a lot of information in there that you will not find elsewhere.
And it provides, I think, an interesting angle to what we've been doing on the company's side.
And I just wanted to spend like a few minutes here to highlight a number of things we've been doing.
We have reduced and committed to reduce our energy consumption and reduce using carbon-related -- or fossil fuel-related consumption.
So currently, almost 80% of the energy we consume, on Scope 1 and Scope 2, is non-fossil fuel.
And if you're not familiar with what Scope 1 and Scope 2 are, I again encourage you to read our sustainability report.
The total carbon footprint of the company, including our tenants, has been reduced by 24% since the last reporting period.
And we have phased around 8,407 tons of CO2 over the reporting period.

I appreciate this number might not be very meaningful for people out there, but that represents around 366 German houses and it's an increase, and we almost doubled the savings of CO2 emissions since last year.
We are very much committed on the topic of carbon emission and reducing CO2 emission.
And we think it's a topic, which is important for the sustainability of the company going forward.
We have been achieving this result by improving our operational performance.

So everything we're doing here on sustainability is also having a positive impact on the overall performance of the company from an operational perspective by mainly centralizing the procurement process for renewable energies across our portfolios.

We are now putting in place a system, which allow us to share the benefit of the prices we're getting in the energy markets with our tenant, and we are rolling over smart meters across the portfolio, which will help us to further improve the overall impact of the portfolio on the CO2 emission.
This -- and I think the work we've been doing has been bearing its fruits.
We have been now, for the second year, consecutive year, in the Group A rating of CDP's Leadership Group A-rating.
We've been publishing our report according to the GRI Standard now.
For the 8th year in a row and for the last 2 years, we've provided third-party insurance on the environmental data that we're providing in the report.
Again, if you have the time and the interest, I would strongly recommend you have a look at our CSR portfolio.
And finally, before we move into the Q&A, I would like to confirm the guidance for -- that we have updated at the last call for the year 2017.
Our revenue EUR 193 million and FFO at EUR 113 million.
That's it from my side.
I would be happy to -- we would be happy to, basically, take your question.
You do have, on the back of the presentation, the reconciliation between the IFRS and the FFO.
And as always, as you know, Ralf and ourselves are available if you have any further questions.
But we are also open now for questions.
Operator?
(Operator Instructions) At the moment, we have no questions.
I hand back to the speaker.
Well, I guess, lunchtime is lunchtime.
And if there is no question, we will be on the road in the coming weeks, and we'll be happy to, basically, discuss with you the results and the sustainability reports when we see you on the road.
Thank you very much for your interest in the company, and we look forward to our next result presentation, which will be the full year results in the course of -- end of February next year.
Thank you very much for your attention, and looking forward to speaking to you later.
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your attendance.
This call has been concluded.
You may disconnect.
